threads.com:
/vrpg/ is a place to discuss all types of role-playing video games, including single-player, multi-player, and massively multi-player, turn-based and real-time action, western-style and JRPG.

Does this mean RPGs are banned on other video game boards? No! /vrpg/ is just a separate board specifically focused on RPGs where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vrpg/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Daggerfall requires a lot of effort on the player to enjoy. A lot of suspension of disbelief. But if you allow yourself to be fooled, it is actually a very fun game. Even though every quest and city is procedurally generated, after you've been playing for a while you kind of allow the illusion that every location is unique to grow on you. You get a sense of scale and realism that no other RPG offers.

I remember Zaric saying that every region in Daggerfall felt unique to him. I thought this was nonsense. How could a region feel unique when it uses the exact same generation algorithm as every other generic region in the game? I didn't understand this until I properly played Daggerfall and gave it a chance rather than dismissing it as procedurally generated garbage like I had done before. For example, over time you remember certain town layouts, you find a city with all the right services that your character requires in the one place, or you grow fond of a city that you've done a lot of quests in. And after a while of helping people out you see your reputation in a region has grown, it feels good that your actions in this world actually mean something.

Daggerfall definitely has something that no other RPG I've played has. A sense of immersion that you really are just an itinerant adventurer living in a fantasy world. Even though it's from 1996 it feels surprisingly modern in the amount of freedom it gives you.

Of course, the Unity version and shit ton of mods help a lot too. There are a lot of quest and world overhaul mods so the game doesn't feel so samey all the time.

threads.com:
DnD based magic systems are retarded and have zero rhyme and reason in their progression. In Kingmaker and WOTR, your caster character can somehow learn the level 7 firestorm spell even if they don't know the level 3 fireball spell. How can a magician cast a higher level spell when they don't even know a much more basic spell? This can also be seen in different schools of magic. Once you reach the level requirement, you can choose advanced illusion spells like Weird even if the only spells you have are evocation spells. It doesn't make any sense. It gets even stupider when you characters can learn spells like Greater Dispel Magic despite not learning the much more basic Dispel Magic.

What is the best magic system in fantasy rpgs?

threads.com:
Looting in warpigs:
>finish a battle
>individually search each and every enemy's corpse and click "take all" along with collecting random bits of cutlery and other garbage littering the room
>become overburdened with useless vendor trash that only exists to be sold
>spend the next few minutes figuring out how to most efficiently distribute the weight between your party, changing equipment to maximise strength bonuses as you do
>head to town to sell everything, making sure to give it all to the party member with the highest barter skill first
>go back to get the rest of the loot
>turns out the merchant doesn't have enough money to buy everything

Looting in jarpigs:
>finish battle
>results screen shows any items you automatically looted, which you can usually carry with effectively no limit
>that's it

Why is it still like this? I'm not even trying to go full weeb and say jarpigs are totally superior, there are definitely things warpigs do better but this isn't one of them. Seriously, why do encumbrance mechanics even still exist? They can't be for realism because they're usually generous enough to let you carry way more than you ever could in reality, and they aren't there as a strategic constraint on the amount of resources you can carry because consumables are typically light and make up maybe 20% of the total weight at most. I like inventory limits in survival horror and some other genres but in any RPG where looting is a major component of the gameplay they need to go, unless maybe the game is really trying hard to be at least somewhat realistic.

>>2874300
While it is true that you can't outright make an strictly "do this to win" guide for most roguelikes, that is more because of the RNG nature of them rather than a fundamental need to "build up mastery" ie you can't have a guide saying "equip item A to dungeon B because there C there" because A, B, and C are more guesses rather guarantees, and the big reason newbies with a guide generally fail to finish their first try is mostly because beating a roguelike is because, for all the talk about roguelikes being about experimentation, most de facto heavily incentivize a very safe, risk averse mentality to success.
You can look at for example Nethack, where the "meta" isn't being daring or manipulating the game mechanics to your advantage per se, but rather just stacking immunities and searching for potions of gain level/wraiths.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
It's not the first JRPG that plays with the concept of darkness. I knew it would be there and I thought I could forgive them.

See, in Japanese the connotation of darkness is closer to words like "secret, hidden, and unknown". It's not completely senseless in English because we have phrases like "to be left in the dark". Although that usage is closer to ignorance; you know, someone who's not "bright" is a "dim wit".

The magical substance, darkness, corrupts nature both physical and mental. It makes sense that someone touched by darkness would lose their memory and sense of self. But it makes less sense that things transformed by darkness turn into something savage and aggressive. In theory you could apply the principle of darkness to zealots, racists, autistics, and erase what they think they know along with any reason to impose. This is where you have to do mental gymnastics to consider the principles of light: truth, understanding, and harmony.
So you can reason the forest wants to kill you because the corruption has removed "harmony". For the sake of the game, we overlook the fact that everything is united against you. It's an illusion of harmony. Realistically, the forest should be a battle royal with monsters fighting monsters.

threads.sub: What is the correct mindset to enjoy DRPGs?
threads.com:
I've tried playing some DRPGs and there's a lot of things I like about them:
>party management
>free character creation, allowing for a multitude of approaches
>first person exploration is usually immersive
>I like drawing maps and making my own notes

Even though I like all these things, there's one thing that always filters me in these games: the combat. No matter how much I try, it seems that all the DRPGs really on two types of battles: the ones where you mash attack until the enemy is dead without worrying about anything and the ones where you try to mash attack to win but the enemy completely destroys your whole party with just one attack. This second option usually becomes a RNG fest, because while the enemy always has this attack that wipes your party, it can use it on turn 1, turn 10 or never use it, so it all comes down to luck.
So, what you do to enjoy this? Do you just accept that combat is shit and decide to have a good time with the remaining characteristics of the game?

Fascism and national socialism have their roots in socialism, just like fascism and socialism have their roots in liberalism. The difference is that fascism and nazism (that is more incoherent form of fascism really) are synthesis of liberal capitalism and socialist tenets. Instead of doing away with private ownership of capital like socialism, fascism tries to eliminate class conflict through meditation between labour and capital with the state being the middleman. In fascism capital, unions and the state work together through corporativist principles in service of the nation's future. So yes, they have the same roots. But no, fascism is opposed to socialism just as it is opposed to naked laizzes faire liberalism. Hence it being the third position in 20th century politics. You can always spot the retard who doesn't know what he's talking about when he claims that fascism equals socialism or communism or he claims that fascism is just the end point of liberal capitalism like commies are wont to do. Just because things share the same roots doesn't mean that they are the same things. Otherwise everything in post French revolution politics is just different shades of liberalism.

threads.com:
What are some tips you can give someone that really wants to get into this game but struggles with the combat?
I love everything about this game, but I find it hard to manage the combat, since there's so many companions, each with a huge array of unique abilities, and it's in real-time (with pause). Micromanagement is not one of my strengths in RPGs, and I'm struggling with this game's combat.
What tips can you give me, lads?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>What are some tips you can give someone that really wants to get into this game but struggles with the combat?
If you're new to real-time-with-pause the pause bit is important when combat is as fast as PoE1. Unless a fight is just filler always pause when giving commands. I play with auto-pause on ability used and enemy killed.
Move your tanks up front and hold position to let the enemies walk up to them while your backline does damage and CC.
Always use per-encounter abilities like Eders knockdown and Aloths Arcane assault before you start with regular attacks.
PoE1 companion AI is pretty shit so micomanagement is kinda required.

last_replies.com:
>>2872193
I am going to assume you're playing on Normal/Hard. If you're on POTD, don't. It's not worth it for a first-timer. Here are a few low micro companions:

Eder - don't bother building him like a tank. Fighters are naturally tanky and are more useful if you build them towards damage. Give him two sabers, plate armor, and let him go to work. There is an armor called Sanguine Plate which you get from a quest in the Vailian Embassy - it is very useful for dual wielding characters. At level 13 he gets Charge which is terrific, but does require you to micro it to use it effectively.

Kana - Build him like a tank. Hatchet and shield for deflection bonuses, plate armor. Early game have him chant Soft Winds of Death constantly for minor AoE damage. At level 9 he can learn the Dragon Thrashed, Dragon Wailed chant. This is one of the best abilities in the game and you will have a massive power increase for Kana. Chant this and nothing else for the rest of the game (except for a certain dragon).

Sagani - having Itumaak means having another body, which is useful. Early game focus on pet abilities - I think they're called Resilient Companion and Vicious Companion. After that build her damage and keep her in the back.

Pallegina - Paladins get an ability at level 13 called Sacred Immolation. It rules. However, level 13 is pretty down the line. Paladins have useful passive bonuses but aren't really damage dealers until then. When you do get Sacred Immolation, the only micro you will have to do is activate it a the beginning of combat.

Zahua - You won't get this guy until you go White March, but you can go to WM fairly early. Plate armor, give him the Torment's Reach ability and no other abilities. Turn on his AI ability usage and he'll just spam this as long as he's gaining wounds. Monks are definitely better with micromanagement, but they can be set up to be fairly effective without it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2874036
With that you have a few tanky characters and one squishy, which should allow you the freedom to micromanage your Watcher/replace a character with one that requires micro. I do have to say that the most powerful classes in the game are the ones who require the most micromanagement - but you can totally beat the game without them. I will say that Priests absolutely make the game easier - buffs such as Devotions of the Faithful are outstanding. Wizards are swiss army knives who become incredibly powerful at later levels - if you fill out Aloth's spell book he will be your most powerful party member. Druids are slightly lesser to Priest/Wizard, but have access to shapeshifting (awesome) and the line of Storm spells (also awesome).

The beginning of the game is the most difficult portion because you have little access to your best abilities. It *will* get easier once you reach mid-levels.

threads.com: What constitutes as good replayability/replay value?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2871746
Good gameplay, multiple viable builds, Skippable scenes, a fast start with no mandatory tutorials.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2872860
It is the fundamental factor in whether or not you want to replay a game.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2871746
In terms of an RPG, replay value = skill checks and build restrictions. If you can be anything, do anything and join/beat any guild or faction in one play through, thats going to sour the replayability. Good replay value consists of making hard decisions with your character build and knowing these decisions will limit your characters future potential. But that also means you know what else could be possible, so in subsequent play-throughs you spec into different points/builds to unlock parts of the game your old build was restricted from.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2873408
My first time through rorona as my first atelier game I had plenty of time, especially once you get the ability to register items and you can complete your assignments pretty much for free. I didn't get the true ending since I missed the dragon event and ignored using some of the other characters. Totori was similar and while I did look up ending requirements toward the end, I messed up by not using gino and marc for too long and didn't have time to get their events. Meruru was even easier, but that game forces ng+ anyways so you really have all the time you could ever need. Though thinking about how the game is set up, I do recall that it has stuff like building that take 30 days to construct and the main tasks that give you the next one a certain number of days after the previous one is complete, so while generous the time limit does stop you from sleeping months away for that kind of stuff.
All of that said, I do think the main thing the time limits bring to the game is that it made the devs make more time specific events, even if there aren't that many. Stuff like the end of year festival in rorona, the beach trip in rorona, or ayesha's contest. And if you want to do stuff like true ending without ng+ or totori's 4000 license points the time limit can add to the challenge. But for normal gameplay it's mostly irrelevant.
